data.title: Region:East Midlands
data.text:
East Midlands

The region of East Midlands in England

CountryUnited Kingdom Number of zones1 052Maximum PPH1 054Last updated2023-04-15

East Midlands is one of twelve regions in the United Kingdom. It consists of Derbyshire, Leicestershire, Lincolnshire (except North and North East Lincolnshire), Northamptonshire, Nottinghamshire and Rutland and has about five million inhabitants.

The East Midlands' largest settlements are Leicester, Nottingham, Derby, Northampton, Chesterfield, Lincoln, Mansfield, Loughborough and Kettering. Leicester is the largest city in the region by unitary authority measurements, whilst the Nottingham Urban Area is its largest conurbation.

Adjacent regions are East of England in the southeast, South East England in the south, West Midlands in the west, North West England in the northwest and Yorkshire & The Humber in the north.

Geographical division[edit]

Municipalities[edit]

In the East Midlands there are nine municipalities with at least one turf zone:

Municipality Zones Derby 39 Derbyshire 341 Leicester 155 Leicestershire 42 Lincolnshire 117 Northamptonshire 111 Nottingham 107 Nottinghamshire 133 Rutland 7

The list is updated according to the zones that existed on 2023-04-15.

Zones[edit]

There are 1052 turf zones in the region of East Midlands, one of which is counted as a world heritage site, one winner zone, one water zone, 34 train station zones, one national park zone, ten monument zones, 76 holy zones, one summit zone, 49 bridge zones, four castle zones and 11 ruin zones.

Updated: 2023-04-15

Zone development[edit]

The first turf zones in the region were 202, all if which were created on June 15, 2013.
